text.p: Following are some of the major events to have occurred on June 17 in history:
656 - Caliph Uthman, third caliph to rule after the death of the Prophet, was assassinated at his home in Medina (now Saudi Arabia) by besieging Moslem rebels from Mesopotamia.
1239 - Edward I, King of England, born. He was king from 1272 on the death of his father Henry III. His rule was notable for its efficiency in administration.
1703 - John Wesley, English evangelist who founded the Methodist movement, born.

1775 - In the American War of Independence, British forces defeated the Americans at the Battle of Bunker Hill which took place at Breed's Hill near Boston. The British won at the cost of 800 out of their force of 2,000.
1789 - In France, the Third Estate proclaimed itself a National Assembly and refused to let the King keep his veto.
1818 - Charles Gounod, French composer, born. Famed for his popular operas including "Faust" and "Romeo et Juliet".
1860 - The 692-foot liner Great Eastern, built by Brunel, left the Isle of Wight on her first transatlantic voyage.
1867 - Joseph Lister performed the first surgical operation under antiseptic conditions on his sister Isabella, at Glasgow's Royal Infirmary.
1882 - Igor Stravinsky, composer, born in Russia. One of the 20th Century's leading musical figures and most famous for his ballets "The Rite of Spring" and "Petrushka".
1925 - Twenty-nine countries signed the Geneva Protocol which prohibited the use of poisonous gases in war.
1940 - Marshal Philippe Petain announced that France had asked for armistice terms from Germany.
1940 - The troop ship Lancastria was sunk by enemy fire after having taken on board British troops who were evacuating from France. Of the 5,300 on board almost 2,480 were saved.
1944 - Iceland became an independent republic following a referendum on disengaging from Denmark's rule.
1967 - China exploded its first hydrogen bomb.
1971 - America and Japan signed an agreement for the return of Okinawa to Japan in 1972.

1972 - In the United States, five men were arrested for attempting to place bugging equipment at the Democratic Party National Committee headquarters in the Watergate building in Washington. This led to President Richard Nixon's resignation in 1974.
1974 - An Irish republican guerrilla bomb exploded at Westminster Hall, in the British Houses of Parliament injuring 11.
1982 - In Argentina, General Leopoldo Galtieri resigned as president following the country's defeat in the Falklands War.
1991 - South Africa's white-dominated parliament voted to end race classification, the legal foundation of apartheid since 1950.
1994 - American football star O.J. Simpson, accused of killing his ex-wife and a male friend, was arrested after a dramatic motorway chase and a 90-minute standoff in the driveway of his estate.
